newsitem.title: ALBANIA: IMF says Albania must deal with pyramids, deficit.
newsitem.headline: IMF says Albania must deal with pyramids, deficit.

text.p: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) on Friday said Albania should deal urgently with the problems of its budget deficit and crooked pyramid investment schemes which sparked widespread rioting in March.
The IMF has had a mission in Albania, which spent 10 days in the country and gave detailed recommendations to Prime Minister Bashkim Fino and President Sali Berisha.
"Albania's economic problems are very serious. We are particularly concerned about two issues, the budget deficit and the resolution of the pyramid scheme problem," the IMF said in a statement.
Albanians pumped huge amounts of money into get-rich-quick pyramid schemes, which swallowed an estimated $1.2 billion.
When several schemes collapsed, thousands of people lost their money and the country erupted in riots and looting.
"Albania needs to resolve the problem of the pyramid schemes once and for all -- both to protect the interests of the depositors and to ensure that new schemes cannot flourish," the IMF added.
It said audits of the schemes should take place to find the insolvent schemes, which should then be closed and have their assets traced as a means to compensate depositors.
Solvent schemes should be controlled by administrators in the interests of depositors, the IMF added.
"We agree with the Albanian authorities that the assets are the only feasible source of compensation for depositors and every effort should be made to recover," it added.
It also said that the country's budget deficit was of concern and would be more than was planned in a 1997 budget passed recently by parliament.
It said the country should keep the deficit under control by rebuilding tax collection, especially customs taxes, increasing some taxes, especially VAT and continuing a tight control of spending.

"The IMF remains to willing to cooperate with Albania. Until the political and security situation is clearer, we cannot discuss a fully worked out economic programme," it added and said it would continue to advise the Albanian authorities.
